content: Honestly, this game is quite fun if you play it solo or even hotseat pass and play is pretty decent implementation. However I can't give it a full five stars because of two issues that combine to make online play almost impossible. One, tabbing out of the app to switch to any other screen (text messaging client for instance) will disconnect the player from the game with no way I'm aware of to reconnect. Added to this is the worse of the two issues, which is the keyboard connection to the game is somehow messed up. It won't allow the use of backspace or enter keys. This breaks in game chat (which exacerbates the other issue, negating the ability to communicate with others while playing). This also breaks private server selection (since the name can't be changed, which is required for selecting the server). In a perfect world, the game wouldn't disconnect every time i switch to my text messaging client. It would also allow reconnection to the same game if I were disconnected. Since the games can take hours, it would also allow saving an online game in progress so it could be reconnected. I'd settle for fixing the keyboard, which would make the game painful and kludgey but at least playable online. My brother's iPhone has no issue with the keyboard. It's a very fun game, just a problematic implementation. Fix the bugs and I'll upgrade my review. And before you suggest it, I have filed a support ticket with Asmodee helpdesk.

Ok, so after playing around 10 games and buying a couple of expansions, these are my thoughts.  Overall,Talisman is a funny and challenging game, at a much  more affordable price than the original boardgame, and with the possibility of playing against characters controlled by the AI, which can be helpful. Despite heavily depending on dice throws and random cards, your decisions and strategy have a lot of weight on the final outcome. Of course, there is a good amount of "chance" or "luck" (whatever you prefer to call it), but that is (as in real life) what makes things interesting, isn't it? ;)  However, there are some issues that need improvement, like the UI, which can be annoying or not very user friendly at some points, or the AI, which after a few games becomes less and less of a challenge. Online gameplaying is also quite limited, specially because of the several hours that can require a game with 5 or 6 players. Fortunately you have the local multiplayer (with pass-and-play possibility) that I think probably is a better option (if you can convince enough friends of course).   Despite these and some other flaws, I believe the game is worth investing a couple of bucks :)

Never played the board game (until long after this one). i've played through all of the characters in Talisman Prologue, and really enjoyed the game. This one is an improvement on every level. The UI is a work of art, both visually and functionally. It's beautifully rendered and animated, as well as easy to use and comfortable on the fingers. It offers additional card/characters sets as IAP, all of which i have purchased (and had no problems using, as some have reported), but the base game already has tons of replay value in it. This is _easily_ my most-played Android game, in terms of number of hours spent in front of it. Nomad support is responsive and they continue to port in expansions and fix bugs. My enjoyment of this game eventually prompted me to buy a physical set, which i also enjoy immensely. Many claim the RNG is weighted in favour of the AI players, but that is provably wrong (via simple experiments involving exiting and replaying a turn using different options). It's an annoying RNG, yes, but it's _provably_ not weighted towards the AI. (That said, i suspect that the AI "knows" what the next roll will be.)

For those that don't know GW = GamesWorkshop. (Look them up.)  Talisman is a fun "tabletop/board" (again look it up) game that should, like many if not all of GW's games, should remain as such.... I wish I didn't waste the six dollars on this one. Folks trust me, I have been playing video games and table top/board games for almost my entire 30 years of life. This abortion of a game is another one GW is making a buck off of from die hard gamers who think "Maybe this one will be better"... The game mechanics of Talisman are solid, be first to "Crown of command" and kill everyone else. But again the randomization, like most all video games that involve dice and/or cards, is the same as the first ever Magic the gathering video game. Yes, I'm talking about the one made first by MicroProse (1997).(L.I.U) Oh look you need anything but a "1" guess what you rolled... Oh whats that, you used a re-roll? Oops another "1"..Alright Bad example, but those that know what I'm talking about get the idea.  One day a company will make a mistake and make the video game a great and fun experience like playing this game in "board" game form (when played with real people, face2face) This ain't it.
